text.p: The following are the main stories from Tuesday morning's Austrian newspapers:
- A mere 27 percent of Austrians are in favour of the introduction of Europe's planned single currency, while as many as 50 percent are outright against it, a new study says.

- Surfing the internet is more expensive in Austria than in any other European country because of high telephone charges, a study by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) shows. Experts now hope cable TV operators may provide cheaper access to cyberspace.
- Austria's net payments to the European Union should be reduced between the years 2000 to 2006 once the bloc has completed its eastward expansion, a parliamentary working group said in a paper.

- Economic research institute IHS said the government should increase subsidies for research and development by almost a third in order to match the amount of money spent on R&D by the majority of developed nations.
- Austria celebrates its number-one tennis player Thomas Muster's victory in Key Biscane, where he was badly injured eight years ago.
- Road accidents in Austria over the Easter weekend claimed nine lives, police said.
- Government negotiations over the 1998/99 budget have begun.
- The governmet plans a new initiative to ward off increasing number of corporate insolvencies.
- Brewery holding BBAG denies reports of a possible sale of its unit Brau AG to drinks giant South African Breweries.
- Education Minister Elisabeth Gehrer says she plans to make teachers' working hours more flexible in order to reduce overtime.
- Car insurance premiums are likely to rise as insurere now have to pay for the full cost of hospital treatment for victims of car accidents.
- The Vienna bourse already has five candidates for its new "fit" market segment for middle-sized businesses, scheduled to be launched during the summer.
